snippet.title: ArcGIS Javascript API #esrijs 4.x - 01 - Getting Started
snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

Full ArcGIS Javascript API Series Playlist http://bit.ly/2zf7G80
 
We are finally here, we made it, the first episode of the Javascript API, y‚Äôall have been waiting for it and its here. Before you start you will need to setup a web server. 

Set install http-server for node js first download and install Nodejs 

https://nodejs.org/en/

Then run this command to install http-server globally

 npm install http-server -g

then you are set.

go to command prompt then navigate to the folder having your HTML and javascript then type 

http-server . 



We start out with the basics, as usual building stuff from scratch, we build our first map and learn about Map and Mapview.

Source code for Episode 1

https://github.com/hnasr/jsapi4x/tree/episode1



Boost your GIS knowledge by grabbing my books

Hussein's GIS Books https://www.husseinnasser.com/books


Stay Awesome!
Hussein Nasser

snippet.title: ArcGIS Javascript API #esrijs 4.x - 20 - Paging
snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

Full ArcGIS Javascript API Series Playlist http://bit.ly/2zf7G80

When you have a layer with hundreds of rows, you probably will need to break the results into multiple "pages" so you can browse through them easily. In this episode we discuss how can we start this work. We look through how google does its paging and we try to mimic something similar.

Code: https://github.com/hnasr/jsapi4x/tree/episode20

snippet.title: ArcGIS Javascript API #esrijs 4.x- 28 - Projecting Spatial Reference with Geometry Service
snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

Full ArcGIS Javascript API Series Playlist http://bit.ly/2zf7G80

Each service that is published to arcgis service must have a spatial reference. When loading a service to the base map geometries must be projected to match the spatial reference of the basemap. In this video we fix a major bug in our map viewer to auto-zoom to the full extent of the service by projecting the service spatial reference to the base map

enjoy!

Background Music: Credit to Abbas AlAnzoor

Source Code
https://github.com/hnasr/jsapi4x/tree/episode28

Administering ArcGIS for Server https://goo.gl/zvYCRg

ArcGIS By Example  https://goo.gl/yJKSqB

Building Web Applications with ArcGIS https://goo.gl/brgKUJ

snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

Today I will wear the software tester hat and start critiquing the application and use github to create issues for bugs and enhancements that I found. Please feel free to do the same! Write down in the comments what you feel we can improve in this application!

Cheers guys
Hussein

snippet.title: ArcGIS Javascript API #esrijs 4.x - 30 - Zoom to Feature
snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

Full ArcGIS Javascript API Series Playlist http://bit.ly/2zf7G80

A long show today! We tackle our first issue number 7 https://github.com/hnasr/jsapi4x/issues/7 where we add a zoom in button to the attribute table. There are lot of things to take care of, code to write, concepts to understand.

First we add the button to each row in the table, then wire the event, and then query to get the geometry of the feature. We make sure to bring back the geometry projected in the basemap spatial reference. Finally based on that geometry, we create an appropriate graphic and zoom to that graphic on the map. 

I enjoyed making this episode hope you guys enjoy it to.

Source code

snippet.title: ArcGIS Javascript API #esrijs 4.x - 34 - Upgrading to version 4.9!
snippet.description:
Hussein's Courses üìê‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/courses
Hussein's Books üìí‚ü∂ https://www.husseinnasser.com/books

In this episode we upgrade to the latest Javascript API which is 4.9, we are currently at 4.5. Learn more about the 4.9 version here. 

https://developers.arcgis.com/javascript/latest/guide/release-notes/


ArcGIS Javascript API can be used to build cool 2D and 3D web apps on top of Esri ecosystem. If you are interested to learn this technology and build apps that solve and streamline your business workflows, check out this series.

Watch me build a full-fledged web maps using this API from scratch/nothing/empty slate. No copy-paste of code *I promise*. Any line I write, I explain. Episode by episode we add new features to our little application, fix bugs and answer questions. 

This video tutorial series are a little different. Here the audience (you) actually request features to be added to the web mapping app, log them into the [github repo] and I look into it and pick up issue one and work on it.

Enjoy! 

https://github.com/hnasr/jsapi4x/tree/episode34

snippet.title: My New GIS Book 2018 Just published on Kindle - Learn GIS Programming
snippet.description:
Buy The Book here : https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07KNHQ8NZ/ref=sr_1_1?s=digital-text&ie=UTF8&qid=1542568174&sr=1-1

The link to the data of the book can be found in Chapter 2, Publishing to ArcGIS Online section, page 33 
I also will put it here 
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1H5Pz28jAtq2CfNUOqpx_U9wxEUUrd7mk/view

Let me know if you have access guys, here is the story of this book.


In late 2012 I got an email from a book publisher author with a proposal to author a book. They have found me through my blog and linked a blog post I wrote back in 2009 on ArcGIS Server technology. I accepted their offer and wrote the book and 3 others that followed.

This makes me question, why did I write that original blog post? I didn‚Äôt know that one day a publisher will google that technology and find my post and make me an offer to write a book. I can‚Äôt remember why exactly I wrote that post but I knew that I was having fun doing it. Sharing my experience with the world through this writing always felt good to me.

In August 2017 I started a new series called Getting Started with ArcGIS Javascript API 4.x on YouTube. That series became really popular. The interaction on that series inspired me to write this book to discuss things I might have missed in that video series and to distill all my findings, knowledge into a book. So if you are new to the YouTube channel consider subscribing to check out more content over there https://www.youtube.com/igeometry

Today, I decided to re-live the experience of writing a book. However, no publisher is backing up this book. This book is written from the heart, full of joy, from me to you. It is a brain dump of what I think will be a very beneficial work for you guys.

As of the time of writing this preface, I did not pick a title of this book. And I‚Äôm feeling good about this. I know the topic and I can imagine how the book will look like. However, I feel that picking a title will force my thoughts through a narrow path and thus limit the potential of what this book could be. Obviously, if you are reading this that means I have already picked a title.

This book is about building web maps using Javascript technology. I picked Javascript because it is a resilient light-weight technology that can run on both the server and the client, mobile, IOT and supercomputer machines. 

Traditional technology books discuss tools. ‚ÄúThis is how to load a web map in a browser‚Äù. ‚ÄúThis is how to query the rest endpoint‚Äù. ‚ÄúThis is how to render a 3d map‚Äù. You get a catalog of tools and what they do. There is nothing wrong with this format. In fact, it is a good reference. However, you don‚Äôt get any context when reading such books to take action and build something. It is like learning what is a hammer, nail and screwdriver does but these tools are useless if no one shows you how to build a table using these tools.

I like to write my books by example, where I build an app and in the process explain the various tools I‚Äôm planning to use to build this app. Personally, I feel this is a better way of learning as it gives context.

I hope you enjoy this book.

What are we building in this book ?
We will be building a web mapping application from scratch. For tourists, we are building an app that helps users locate landmarks. The app shows the landmarks in a map such as libraries, cafes, restaurants schools and much more. It has a search capability to search for landmarks where they will be highlighted on the map. It also shows the nearby landmarks within specific miles from current location. So you can answer interesting questions such as show me all libraries within 100 feet of this coffee shop or are there any liquor stores within a mile from this school? I will be providing you with the sample data which I created myself, this data is not real it is just sample. All we need is to write the application. The app will run on both mobile and desktop.

Don‚Äôt worry if this seems like a lot. We will break down those functionalities into different chapters and slowly walk through each.

Who this book is written for?
Anyone interested in learning how to build a web mapping application. Basic programming knowledge is recommended but not required. I will explain all that is required as we go through the book.

System Requirements
I designed this book in a way so you don‚Äôt require a special or license to get started. I will be using a mac in this book but will include instructions for Windows and Linux. We will use ArcGIS Online free account to host our landmark data and ArcGIS Javascript API 4.x to write the web application. I will provide that data in GeoJSON format so we can upload it to ArcGIS Online.

Software Requirements
All you need on your machine is a text editor to write code and a web server to serve the static files. I will be using Node JS as a web server and Visual Studio Code as the text editor. We will take care of the download and installation of those two in chapter 1.
